Nomenclatural remarks. According to
Stichel ( 1955 )
, the gender of the genus name
Hydrometra
is masculine rather than feminine; and consequently the name of this species should be
H. gracilentus
Horváth, 1899
rather than
Hydrometra gracilenta
Horváth, 1899
. This proposed change seems to have been almost entirely overlooked by subsequent authors, and was rarely quoted and however never discussed ( e.g. , cf.
Adlbauer 1979
;
Tamanini 1989
; Andersen 1995 ;
Aukema 2015
).

Latreille ( 1797 : 86 )
described the genus
Hydrometra
without specifying its gender. Etymologically, the scientific name is composed by the Latin prefix hydro- (from the Greek word ὕδωρ [ hýdōr ] = ‘water’) and the Greek term Μετρης [ -métrēs ] = ‘that measures’, so literally “that measures the water” ( cf.
Oli and Magini 1987
); comparable to the Latin word “ gĕōmetrēs , ae ”, a masculine name.

The word “
hydrometra
” did not exist in classical Latin, but in the neo-Latin of the late 18 th century, a word ending in “ -a ” was simply considered feminine. According to the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature ( ICZN 1999 , Art. 30.1.3) “a genus-group name that is a Greek word latinized with change of ending, or with a Latin or latinized suffix, takes the gender normally appropriate to the changed ending or the Latin suffix”.

paragraph.bibRef:
Finally, P.A.
Latreille published his “ Précis des caractères génériques des insectes [...]” at his own expense in 1797 ( cf.
Michelsen & O’Hara 2014
), so the year of description of the genus Hydrometra is here reported as 1797 , even if until now it has been incorrectly stated as
1796
( e.g. , Andersen
1995
;
Aukema
2015
).
